item.title: Gearbox Shares Some Funny Borderlands 4 Opening Weekend Stats
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Borderlands 4 arrived last week, and planet Kairos is ripe for the looting. Gearbox Studios has released a handful of stats from Borderlands 4 that reveal just how far some players are willing to go to find loot.

According to the graph, 1,530,794 items were looted from an outhouse. Who knew there was so much treasure to be found there?! By comparison, only 487,585 items were looted from trashcans, which apparently means there's more to be gained from going into an outhouse than digging through a normal trash receptacle. Players also looted 1,811,970 items from boomboxes, beer coolers, and grills. However, red chests comfortably took the top slot with 14,814,296 items looted in the first weekend.

Getting all of that treasure didn't happen without a price; 2,034,399 players suffered an unfortunate end by barrel. Grenade fatalities were even higher with 4,563,416. Although deaths by toxic goo were much smaller with 349,734, those are the ones that looked like they hurt the most.

Among the game's vehicles, exactly 16,220,852 were destroyed, although the stat doesn't break it down by vehicle. Players attempted 62,718,658 boss battles, and 55,403,323 bosses fell in defeat. However, there were 16,220,852 failed boss encounters that left the players on the losing end.

Additionally, Gearbox shared a code for the Break Free Pack and two ECHO-4 drone skins: JS63J-JSCWJ-CFTBW-3TJ3J-WJS5R.

Although Borderlands 4 had primarily positive critical reviews, PC players have been very vocal on Steam about performance and optimization issues. Gearbox Studios CEO Randy Pitchford has disputed players' accounts and remained defiant about the issue while also offering optimization tips. Pitchford also noted that a PS5 Pro patch is in the works to combat issues on that console.

Borderlands 4 is out now for Xbox Series X|S, PlayStation 5, and PC. The Switch 2 port will be released on October 3. If you're looking for help, check out GameSpot's Borderlands 4 guides hub for several helpful features, tips, and tricks.

item.title: All Tricks In Skate And How To Do Them
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

While Skate limits you to some simple flip tricks and grinds at the beginning of the game, there's so much than meets the eye. Skate offers over 100 tricks you can perform while on your board, and there are even some different tricks for wiping out with your character. You're free to figure out how to perform each of these tricks on your own time, but why not take a peek at everything that's possible?

Table of Contents [hide]

  • All tricks in Skate
    • Flip Tricks
    • Grinds
    • Grab Tricks

Below, you can see every currently available trick in Skate and the buttons required to perform each one. As a note, the developers have confirmed more tricks are on the way, so we'll be updating this guide as tricks are added to the game.

All tricks in Skate

The different tricks in Skate are divided up into several categories, including: Flip Tricks, Grinds, Grab Tricks, and Off-Board. You can find all of these tricks by going to the Skatepedia, which is found in the settings section of the main menu.

We will divide each trick up by its given category and then provide you with the button combination needed to perform each one. We won't be including the "Riding" section of the Skatepedia, though, as those are more mechanical and not actual tricks.

Flip Tricks

Ollie Tricks

  • Ollie - Right Stick (RS) Up
  • Kickflip - RS Up and Right
  • Heelflip - RS Up and Left
  • FS Pop-Shuvit - RS Left
  • BS Pop-Shuvit - RS Right
  • Varial Kickflip - RS flick Down/Left then Up/Right
  • Varial Heelflip - RS flick Down/Right then Up/Left
  • 360 Flip - RS flick Left, Down, and Up/Right
  • Laserflip - RS flick Right, Down, and Up/Left
  • Hardflip - RS flick Down, Down/Right, and Up
  • Inward Heelfip - RS flick Down, Down/Left, and Up
  • FS 360 Pop-Shuvit - RS Down/Right then drag Left
  • BS 360 Pop-Shuvit - RS Down/Left then drag Right
  • 360 Hardflip - RS flick Right, Down, and Up
  • 360 Inward Heelfip - RS flick Left, Down, and Up

Nollie Tricks

  • Nollie - RS flick Up and Down
  • Nolle Kickflip - RS flick Up and Down/Right
  • Nollie Heelflip - RS flick Up and Down/Left
  • Nollie FS Pop-Shuvit - RS flick Up and drag Right
  • Nollie BS Pop-Shuvit - RS flick Up and drag Left
  • Nollie Varial Kickflip - RS flick Up/Left and Down/Right
  • Nollie Varial Heelflip - RS flick Up/Right and Down/Left
  • Nollie 360 Flip - RS flick Up/Left, Up, and Down/Right
  • Nollie Laserflip - RS flick Up/Right, Up, and Down/Left
  • Nollie Hardflip - RS flick Up and slightly to the Right, Up, and Down/Right
  • Nollie Inward Heelflip - RS flick Up and slightly to the Left, Up, and Down/Left
  • Nollie FS 360 Pop-Shuvit - RS flick Up/Left and drag to Up/Right
  • Nollie BS 360 Pop-Shuvit - RS flick Up/Right and drag to Up/Left
  • Nollie 360 Hardflip - RS flick Right, Up, and Down/Right
  • Nollie 360 Inward Heelflip - RS flick Left, Up, and Down/Left

Flip Trick Modifiers

  • Late Flip Tricks - RS flick Down and Up/Right
  • Held Flip Tricks - RS flick Down and Up/Right and then hold the stick in position in mid-air
  • Boned Ollie - Hold RS Up
  • Front Foot One-Foot Ollie - A/X (in-air)
  • Back Foot One-Foot Ollie - X/Square (in-air)

Grinds

Grind Tricks

  • FS 50-50 Grind - RS Down and Up
  • BS 50-50 Grind - RS Down and Up
  • FS 5-0 - Hold RS Down in-air
  • BS 5-0 - Hold RS Down in-air
  • FS Nose Grind - Hold RS Up in-air
  • BS Nose Grind - Hold RS Up in-air
  • FS Crooked - Hold RS Up/Left in-air
  • BS Crooked - Hold RS Up/Left in-air
  • FS Overcrook - Hold RS Up/Right in-air
  • BS Overcrook - Hold RS Up/Right in-air
  • FS Salad - Hold RS Down/Right in-air
  • BS Salad - Hold RS Down/Right in-air
  • FS Smith - Hold RS Right and Up in-air
  • BS Smith - Hold RS Right and Up in-air
  • FS Feeble - Hold RS Left and Up in-air
  • FS Willy - Hold RS Left and Down in-air
  • BS Willy - Hold RS Left and Down in-air
  • FS Over Willy - Hold RS Right and Down in-air
  • BS Over Willy - Hold RS Right and Down in-air
  • FS Boardslide - Hold RS Left in-air
  • BS Boardslide - Hold RS Left in-air
  • FS Lipslide - Hold RS Right in-air
  • BS Lipslide - Hold RS Right in-air
  • FS Noseslide - Hold RS Up and Left in-air
  • BS Noseslide - Hold RS Up and Left in-air
  • FS Tailside - Hold RS Down and Left in-air
  • BS Tailside - Hold RS Down and Left in-air
  • FS Bluntslide - Hold RS Down and Right in-air
  • BS Bluntslide - Hold RS Down and Right in-air
  • FS Nose Blunt - Hold RS Up and Left in-air
  • BS Nose Blunt - Hold RS Up and Left in-air
  • Grind Exit - LS Left or Right

Grab Tricks

Basic Grab Tricks

  • BS Grab - Hold RT/R2
  • FS Grab - Hold LT/L2
  • Double Grab - Hold LT/L2 + RT/R2
  • Tail Grab - Hold Up on RS + LT/L2
  • Nose Grab - Hold Down on RS + RT/R2
  • Stale Grab - Hold Right on RS + LT/L2
  • Weddle Grab - Hold Right on RS + RT/R2
  • Crail Grab - Hold Down on RS + LT/L2
  • Seatbelt - Hold Up on RS + RT/R2
  • Rocket Air - Hold Down on RS + RT/R2 and LT/L2

Modified Grab Tricks

  • Nosebone - Hold LT/L2 + RS Up
  • Tailbone - Hold LT/L2 + RS Down
  • Tuck Knee - Hold LT/L2 + RS Right
  • Stiffy - Hold LT/L2 + RS Left
  • BS Tweak - Hold RT/R2 + RS Down
  • Melon - Hold RT/R2 + RS Up
  • Cross Bone - Hold RT/R2 + RS Left
  • Method - Hold RT/R2 + RS Right
  • Tail Nosebone - Hold RS Up then LT/L2 + RS Up
  • FS Shifty Tail Grab - Hold RS Up then LT/L2 + RS Right
  • BS Shifty Tail Grab - Hold RS Up then LT/L2 + RS Left
  • Nose Tailbone - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + RS Down
  • FS Shifty Nose Grab - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + RS Right
  • BS Shifty Nose Grab - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + RS Left
  • Stale BS Tuck Knee - Hold RS Right then LT/L2 + RS Right
  • Stale Tailbone - Hold RS Right then LT/L2 + RS Down
  • Stale Nosebone - Hold RS Right then LT/L2 + RS Up
  • Japan Air - Hold RS Right then RT/R2 + RS Left
  • Weddle Tailbone - Hold RS Right then RT/R2 + RS Down
  • Weddle Nosebone - Hold RS Right then RT/R2 + RS Up
  • FS Shifty Crail - Hold RS Down then LT/L2 + RS Left
  • BS Shifty Crail - Hold RS Down then LT/L2 + RS Right
  • FS Shifty Seatbelt - Hold RS Up then LT/L2 + RS Left
  • BS Shifty Seatbelt - Hold RS Up then LT/L2 + RS Right
  • Double Grab Mod Tail - LT/L2 + RT/R2 then hold RS Down
  • Double Grab Mod Nose - LT/L2 + RT/R2 then hold RS Up
  • Double Grab Mod Left - LT/L2 + RT/R2 then hold RS Left
  • Double Grab Mod Right - LT/L2 + RT/R2 then hold RS Right

One-Foot Grab Tricks

  • Frigid Air - LT/L2 + A/X
  • FS One-Foot - LT/L2 + X/Square
  • Judo Air - RT/R2 + X/Square
  • One-Foot Air - RT/R2 +A/X
  • Dog Piss - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + X/Square
  • Judo Nose Grab - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + A/X
  • Benihana - Hold RS Up then RT/R2 + X/Square
  • One-Foot Tail Grab - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + A/X

No Foot Grab Tricks

  • Airwalk - Hold RS Down then RT/R2 + B/Circle
  • Tailwalk - Hold RS Up then RT/R2 + B/Circle
  • Christ Air - RT/R2 + B/Circle
  • No-Foot Air - LT/L2 + B/Circle
  • Superdue - LT/L2 + RT/R2 + B/Circle

Ground Grab Tricks

  • Frontside Ground Grab - LT/L2 while rolling
  • Backside Ground Grab - RT/R2 while rolling
  • Double Ground Grab - LT/L2 + RT/R2 while rolling
  • Coffin - LT/L2 + RT/R2 + X/Square + A/X

Hand Plants

  • BS Handplant - RB/R1
  • FS Handplant - LB/L1

Foot Plant Tricks

  • Bean Plant - RT/R2 + A/X
  • FS Fastplant - RT/R2 + X/Square
  • FS Boneless - LT/L2 + A/X
  • FS Fastplant - LT/L2 + X/Square

We'll see how many tricks get added to this list over time, but those are your options right now in Skate.

item.title: Congressional Republican Calls On Discord, Steam, Twitch CEOs To Testify About Radicalization
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

James Comer, a Republican representative from Kentucky and the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, has called on the CEOs of major game-adjacent and forum platforms to appear at an upcoming panel about online radicalization. Coming in the aftermath of the murder of right-wing influencer Charlie Kirk, Comer seeks testimony from the leadership at Valve, Discord, Twitch, and Reddit.

In a press release, Comer stated that government has a "duty to oversee the online platforms that radicals have used to advance political violence." Comer further explained that the CEOs must "explain what actions they will take to ensure their platforms are not exploited for nefarious purpose."

As such, the CEOs have each been sent letters requesting their presence at a House Oversight Committee hearing that will take place on October 8. According to the letters, the hearing will address "radicalization of online forum users, including incidents of open incitement to commit violent politically motivated acts."

Information released about the suspect in Kirk's murder suggests that he was an avid internet user and game player. In addition to engraving references to online memes and, apparently, a Helldivers 2 button combination on shell casings, the suspect also extensively used Discord, had a Steam account, and was described as "terminally online" by friends. These pieces of evidence, combined with debate around online response in the immediate aftermath, have resulted in calls from conservative officials and media to crack down on social media companies.

However, a research community already exists that has attempted to tease out the complex, sensitive, and multifaceted relationship between gaming cultures and communities and violent radicalization. In recent years, researchers (including myself) have devoted time and attention to studying gaming cultures and communities. Sparked by high-profile violent attacks whose perpetrators referenced gaming culture or were radicalized within games-adjacent social media, this research has focused on how socialization and relationship-building within the context of online games may interact with radicalization to violent extremism. For instance, I have worked for years with collaborators to investigate how often game players are exposed to hate speech and harassment within games, niche communities of violent extremists on Steam, and methods for building resilience to radicalization among game communities.

This research community has long been careful to focus on cultural and social dynamics and where they intersect with gaming broadly, and to communicate that there is little evidence of any direct link between gaming and violence. Video games are commonly targeted by influencers and policymakers after violent events, despite scant evidence as to a direct link between gameplay and violence. Social scientists have studied the effects of gaming since the 1990s and have found mixed results, at most, for the controversial claims around games and violence.

Despite this caution and its focus on understanding exactly when, why, and whether violence in online communities occurs in gaming contexts, this research community has been significantly curtailed by recent initiatives by the current US administration. Much of my research, for instance, was funded by the Department of Homeland Security's Targeted Violence and Terrorism Prevention grant program, which was significantly scaled back in July. Other violence prevention research was funded by the National Institute for Health, which has also undergone severe cuts to its grantmaking efforts.
